21 reconciliation bills have become law throughout history, most recently when Republican's enacted their antigrowth tax bill in 2017. Both parties have taken advantage of reconciliation over the years, and there's no reason a reconciliation bill cannot be bipartisan.

‚û°Ô∏èAfter committees report out their pieces, the Budget Committee compiles all the bills into a single package that will be considered by the House & Senate.

‚û°Ô∏èIf the House & Senate adopt different versions, they must resolve any differences before a final bill is sent to @POTUS.

üëâCommittees develop legislation aligned w/ the reconciliation instructions, though all policy details are left up to committee discretion.

(i.e. I'll join my @EnergyCommerce colleagues tomorrow to markup our section of the COVID-19 reconciliation bill:
https://energycommerce.house.gov/committee-activity/markups/budget-reconciliation-pursuant-to-sconres-5-the-concurrent-resolution-on)

‚úÖThese instructions are sent to committees of jurisdiction and outline (1) the amount of $$$ each committee can earmark for the budgetary changes to be made over a certain time frame, and (2) reporting deadlines.
https://news.yahoo.com/house-committees-covid-19-relief-142702291.html

The current reconciliation timeline:
‚úÖCongress creates & passes a budget resolution (a plan agreed upon by the House & Senate) for the upcoming Fiscal Year. The reconciliation process is triggered when specific instructions are included in the resolution.
https://scottpeters.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-peters-helps-house-pass-budget-resolution-starting-reconciliation

Reconciliation is a special process that helps lawmakers change tax and mandatory spending policy. It's a tool often used to expedite time-sensitive legislation: a reconciliation bill only requires a simple majority (50 +1 votes) in the Senate instead of the traditional 60 votes.

Put simply, HR 1 will make our democracy function better for the American people, who it is intended to serve. I am proud to be a cosponsor of this bill and will never stop working to improve our democracy.

And by investing in election infrastructure, including voting machines made in the US, and election security, like cybersecurity protections, HR 1 will give all Americans the assurance they need to know their vote was correctly counted and their elections were secure.

To ensure elected officials are working with the best interests of their constituents, not themselves, top of mind, HR 1 enacts strict ethics requirements and conflict of interest guidelines, for members of Congress, the White House, and Supreme Court justices.

It's no secret that corporations have undue influence in DC and, this fall, North Texans had to suffer through the onslaught of misleading ads by dark money groups. This bill addresses these issues by increasing transparency and requiring clearer disclosures of who's funding ads.

HR 1 will also make it easier for Americans to cast their ballots by establishing a national early vote period, expanding access to absentee voting, and requiring states to notify voters of a polling location change at least a week before the election, something I introduced.

Starting with making sure more Americans can register to vote by automatically registering every eligible unregistered American citizen, limiting the ability to kick registered voters off the roles, and allowing folks to register on Election Day.

HR 1 is the most comprehensive democratic reform and anti-corruption legislation in a generation. It will help put democratic power squarely in the hands of the American people, eroding the power of dark money and making it easier and more secure for eligible Americans to vote.

11. And once we're through this, let's not forget this moment.  There are consequences of starving our public health system and failing to provide resources to the local government agencies that are on the frontlines of this pandemic.  We can - and must - do better.  /fin
10. This will get easier as more vaccines come to market, as production ramps up and as more federal coordination comes into play with the Biden administration.  Until then, be patient.

9. And while some regions are doing a much better job than others at getting "shots into arms" let's all make sure we measure success in absolute rather than relative terms.  Crushing COVID depends not on my county doing better than your county, but on all of us working together.

8. There is no "right" answer to that trade off.  But please appreciate that good, well intentioned people are trying to manage those equities as best they can.  It's a hard job, and we owe them our thanks.

7. That's why this is both a public health AND political problem.  A bus driver working 2 shifts a day is going to be harder to schedule a vaccination appointment for than a wealthy senior citizen who spends all day at home.  But they also present very different rates of spread.

6. And keep in mind that our metrics of success aren't perfect.  Maximizing the % of a population that is vaccinated isn't exactly the same as minimizing spread given the ranges of living / work situations that different human beings have.
5. They have more responsibility than authority and are making the most of that situation.  Show them some love and patience as they grapple with the cards they have been dealt.

4. Please don't take this out on public health officials.  None of them are happy with the number of COVID cases, nor the vaccine supply they have available.  All are working hard to address a problem that is as much a public health crisis as a political one.

3. That is starting to improve, but public health officials are still grappling with multiple databases, supply channels and vendors who are not all in sync.  Different definitions of 1A, 1B by region, different ability to get yourself on relevant databases are the result.

2. Among those issues is the lack of any federal coordination during the prior administration.  From PPE to ventilators to testing to vaccines, states had to compete with each other rather than work collaboratively to crush the virus.

1. As I noted at the DuPage fairgrounds yesterday, we have to play the cards we have, not the cards we wish we had.  My height and vertical leap means I won't ever dunk a basketball. The process of vaccine rollout to date has created similar near-term challenges.
